question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me about different models of evolution, how to create an engaging presentation, and the various debates about humanity's origin and progression in its early years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Learning to read phylogenetic trees
Learning essential vocabulary to discuss evolutionary genetics
Reading and discussing primary literature
Giving presentations over primary literature
Interpretation of dense figures/phylogeny trees

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Reading papers
2. Better understanding of the terms and concepts involved in evolutionary genomics
3. Examining sources from a critical perspective

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to find, understand, and synthesize scientific literature. I also learned about a lot of evolutionary concepts that I had never heard about before and I learned how to give an effective presentation at a higher level when the material is complex.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
- how introgression and lineage sorting are ways to describe evolutionary patterns
- there are different methods to genome sequencing (illumina, etc.)
- how evolutionary biology is applicable to agriculture, medicine, sleep, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Evolutionary genomics 
2. Reading scientific articles.
3. Introgression

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Projects and group discussions kept me engaged in class and helped teach me about various complex concepts. I would keep these assignments for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Presentations on Tuesday and then discussion on Thursday 
Presentations would help define vocabulary terms/key concepts/figures from the literature
Yoder helped us understand the many evolutionary theories
Liked sending Yoder discussion questions for Thursday's class

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Yoder always kept the discussion going naturally and had interesting insights to offer on anything anyone said. I liked the discussions we had about papers and how they were very conversational, and Dr. Yoder was very good at inviting people to speak without putting too much pressure on them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked having readings each week that we read on our own and then discussed as a class. Dr. Yoder did a good job of explaining the readings, although some aspects of the content were a little confusing. I really liked having no tests so that we could focus on learning the content at our own pace and be curious without worrying about our grade.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the student-led discussion series, where a group presented on an evolutionary biology topic -- it was both engaging as a group presenter and hearer, and to have learned the different applications come to life.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the part Dr. Yoder allow us to discuss with peers and have a whole group instruction is a great way to facilitate my learning. I also like the part that we have readings to do during the week.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The group projects made this class stimulating, but I would have learned more with more in-class examples and discussions as opposed to just lectures.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the second half of the class that put the core concepts learned in the 1st half of the course into relevant/interesting topics. Discussions over modern medical implications were very interesting and gave relevance to it all. I also liked the group discussion presentations done in a chronological order to show the progression of research done in this field.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Applying the concepts to papers was always a fun challenge and it helped me understand the theory more.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Dr. Yoder made an effort to connect with her students all semester and present new, interesting ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think a lot of the materials were up in the air -- and often it was hard to follow the materials being discussed since it was hard to grasp. Having the lectures be more concise and digestible, through videos? might be helpful as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the part students could present their projects and Dr. Yoder lead a big class discussion is the most stimulating part.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Put a substantial amount of time into creating and practicing for presentations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Be prepared to read a lot of primary literature
Be prepared to sit with being confused with specific topics (especially in the beginning)
Come ready to speak in discussions/small groups/class presentations

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to any student interested in biological sciences, since evolutionary genomics is at the forefront of this field and having an understanding of it would be greatly beneficial.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you participate all semester and send in your questions each week. This course is not stressful at all if you stay on top of the readings and start the very few assignments ahead of time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Ready to get hard in genomics. The class is not hard for a grade, but it will be hard if you want to understand many concepts and details.
